content.text: Hi, I'm Joshua Wright. In this series of videos, we'll take a look at the steps to complete the lab exercises associated with your course material. In this first video, we'll look at our Lab Zero Setup Steps. These steps are designed to help you get your system set up to be able to participate in all the lab exercises that we'll do through our class.

SANS will send you an email after signing up for class, giving you access to the Lab Zero Setup Guide. I've downloaded that PDF file to my computer here. And in this guide, I talk about the objective for this Lab Setup Guide, getting your system set up, and also some requirements. It's important that your system meet the requirements for the lab exercises. For example, you will need a workstation that meets the requirements. You can click on the link here to see the class, laptop, or desktop requirements on the SANS website.

You'll also need to download the ISO media file. Now, this is a pretty big file. I have a copy of the file here, but yours may be a slightly different file name. And this will take a little bit of time to download. I recommend you download that file and then back it up somewhere safe so that you can always return to these lab exercises anytime you want.

Finally, you will also need a copy of VMware. That could be Workstation Pro, VMware Workstation Player, or Fusion if you're running on a Mac. Right now, I'm working from my Windows system to show the lab setup directions. But I'll also show you setup directions from a Mac towards the end of this video. I also have VMware Workstation here, but again, you could have Workstation Player, the free version or even a trial version, and any of those VMware Workstation products will work fine.

Now, to get started here, what I recommend is you create a desktop folder called SEC504. So I'm going to right-click on my desktop and choose New Folder, and I'm going to name that SEC504. You could, of course, put this in a different location on your file system, but just somewhere where it's going to be convenient for you.

Next, double-click to open the ISO media file. This is pretty straightforward. We're going to double-click on the ISO media file. We're going to get a security warning here, but it's okay to open this file. I'm going to click Okay. And it will show you all of the files associated with our lab content.

Now, the next step is to highlight all of these files and drag and drop them into the SEC504 folder here. This copy procedure will take a few minutes to complete, so we'll resume the video once all the files have copied. Great.

Now that all the files have copied, we can continue with our lab setup directions here. And we're going to close the ISO media folder here. You can also optionally unmount this DVD drive letter. That's actually a good idea because you won't make a mistake as to what source of the files you're working from. We want to work from this SEC504 desktop folder, not the read-only ISO media files. So I'm going to right-click on this and choose the Eject button. Great.

Now, I'm going to open the desktop SEC504 folder by double-clicking on it here. And one thing that does help make things a little bit easier to navigate is if you click View, and then you click this checkbox here to display File name extensions. By default, Windows Explorer doesn't show file name extensions. You may already have that turned on, and if so, that's fantastic. But I recommend turning it on, so you can see what the files are and, a little bit more accurately, what kind of file types that you're going to work with.

Next, we're going to install the software called 7-Zip. 7-Zip is the software we'll need to extract the virtual machines we will use for class. And we include that in the utilities directory. I'm going to double-click on utilities, go to windows, and then double-click on the 7-Zip installer. I'm going to accept the defaults to install 7-Zip on my system and then choose Close. Great.

Now, we're going to go back to this SEC504 folder. And then we're going to navigate to the virtual_machines folder here. Now, there's two 7-Zip files here. These are the two large files that are included with your ISO media files. And they represent the virtual machines that you'll use for all the lab exercises. You'll get a Slingshot Linux virtual machine and a Windows 10 virtual machine. Now, these virtual machines I've customized for use in lab exercises. You will need these two virtual machines for all the lab exercises you'll complete throughout this class.

What we want to do here is extract these two virtual machines. We'll start with Slingshot Linux. I'm going to right-click on this, go to the 7-Zip folder or 7-Zip nav menu that's been added, and then click on Extract Here. This will ask 7-Zip to extract the virtual machine files for Slingshot Linux. And this process will take a couple of minutes, so we'll resume the video when this step completes.

Once 7-Zip finishes extracting the Slingshot Linux virtual machine, we can repeat that step for the Windows 10 virtual machine. I'm going to right-click on the Windows 10 7-Zip file and choose 7-Zip and then Extract Here. This virtual machine's a little bit smaller, so it will complete a little bit faster, and we will resume this video when 7-Zip finishes extracting the Windows virtual machine. Fantastic.

As a reminder, you can always return to the 7-Zip files and re-extract them. Say, for example, you have made a mistake in a lab exercise that you can't recover from or deleted some files that you want to have restored. One easy way to fix a broken lab exercise is to remove the virtual machine, and then re-extract it from the 7-Zip file again, and then you know you're working with a fresh copy of that virtual machine content.

Next, we'll continue on here. We've extracted the Windows and the Slingshot Linux virtual machines. And we can next open and run the virtual machines inside of VMware. You can close this Explorer window here. And I'm going to navigate to VMware Workstation here. I've got the icon on my desktop. And after a couple of seconds, VMware Workstation will open, and then you can choose to Open a Virtual Machine, or if you're using VMware Player, I think you have to click File and then Open, specifically, but either way, it will open an open dialogue box, and then you can navigate to your desktop folder, and then SEC504, and then virtual_machines.

And then we'll start with the Slingshot Linux virtual machine. You can start with either one. And then you'll see this VMX file. The VMX file is the configuration file. There's a second file in that directory, the VMDK, which is a virtual machine disk file. Select the VMX file and then choose Open. And then VMware will open up a tab or in a new window, show you the virtual machine, and then you can click Power on this virtual machine.

And VMware will take a few seconds to be able to boot up the virtual machine. But after several seconds, we should see the graphical user interface and a log-in prompt dialogue here. And then when prompted to enter a password, you can enter the password that's the same as the username, sec504, and then click the Log In button. Fantastic.

Now, we can repeat this open process for the other virtual machine, in my case, the Windows virtual machine. From VMware Workstation here, I can click File, Open. If you are using VMware Player though, to have two virtual machines running at the same time, you need to relaunch VMware Player. But either way, relaunch a second instance of VMware Player or from VMware Workstation, you can click File and then Open again, return to the desktop SEC504 folder and then Virtual Machines, and this time, choose the Windows directory. Select the Windows VMX file and then click Open. Once VMware opens up the window, and you can see here, I've got different tabs for the two virtual machines, you can click on Power on this virtual machine.

One slight difference with Windows is that VMware will prompt you, has this virtual machine been moved or copied? This is a question that VMware asks to know if it should generate a new MAC address and other unique identifiers specific to the Windows operating system. It says here, "If you don't know, answer, "I Copied It"." And indeed, that is what we want here. Choose I Copied It when prompted.

VMware will start up the Windows virtual machine here. This will take a few seconds to finish. And then once you get to the splash screen, you can double-click. And then you will see the SANS Institute End User License Agreement or the EULA. With this class, SANS grants you four months of access to be able to use this Windows virtual machine. There is no technical limitation that stops a virtual machine from working after four months, but you are obligated to have an independent license for Windows 10 from Microsoft to continue using the virtual machine for another four months. Click OK after you've read and understand this license agreement. And then when prompted, enter the same password that we use for Slingshot Linux, same as the username here, sec504, all lowercase letters.

Now, depending on your screen resolution and the density of your display on your system, you may have a very large display like I have here, or your display may look just right if you have a high DPI display. If you have some kind of excessively large icons here and you want to change that, you can right-click on the desktop. Go to not Personalize but Display Settings. Right-click Display Settings. And then you can change the size of text and apps and other items from 125 or even larger to 100%, and Windows will resize that for you automatically. If you want to change your resolution, you can manually do so here, or if you want to change your screen size, whatever makes sense for your system and whatever's easiest for you to view specifically.

Now, I like to keep my virtual machines in a full screen mode. You will be asked to switch back and forth between virtual machines for several of the lab exercises, so some people like to keep them in different windows or in different tabs, and that's fine if that's what you want to do. I prefer to keep my virtual machines in full screen mode to maximize the screen real estate and turn off or rather hide some of these different menu options.

So I'm going to click on the Enter full screen mode option for this virtual machine. And then it will resize automatically to display my virtual machine in full screen mode. If I move my mouse to the top of my screen and just let it sit for a second, I will get a little pop-up menu from VMware where I can change to my other virtual machine, and you can see how that is also in full screen mode here.

Now, from these two virtual machines, we can also change our font sizes as well. If you go to the web browser here, you can start the web browser, and then you can press Ctrl+Plus or Ctrl+Minus to be able to increase or decrease the font size here. We're going to spend a lot of time in the Terminal. We open a terminal, it's very similar, Ctrl+Shift+Plus or Ctrl+Minus to be able to increase or decrease that font size. And if you want to make that preference permanent, you can click Edit, Profiles, choose the Default profile and then click Edit. And then you can change the font size to whatever your preference is here.

Very similarly for our Windows virtual machine, when I went full screen, it made my icons a little large again, so I'm going to go back to Display Settings. Okay. I changed my scale to 175. I'm going to change it back to 125. When I went full screen, that looks a little bit better for me.

We are going to spend quite a bit of time in PowerShell. And I have increased the default font size for PowerShell, from 10-point up to something a little bit larger, here at 16-point. But you can increase or decrease that based off of your preferences and what's easy and convenient for you to view. On Windows, we will use Chrome for our browser. Very similarly, Ctrl+Plus and Ctrl+Minus can increase or decrease the font size.

Now, that's it for our setup directions for Windows. Next, we'll take a look at the similar setup directions if you're using a Mac system. You could also use an Apple Mac system for the lab exercises, but only if your Apple Mac system is of the Intel processor variety. Unfortunately, the newer Mac models that use the M1, M2, and M3 chips do not support VMware in the ability to virtualize the virtual machines that we use for lab exercises. I'm going to talk through the steps to be able to set up a Mac system, but again, this only applies for Intel-based Mac systems.

For Intel-based Mac systems, you will also start by installing VMware, and then downloading the ISO media file that I have here. You can double-click on the ISO media file, very similar to what we did for Windows. Now, for most users, that will start Finder automatically. For some reason, my system doesn't open Finder automatically. So I'm just going to press Command+N to open up a new Finder window. And then I can see that I do indeed have the ISO media file copied here.

Now, I'm going to right-click on my desktop, and I'm going to create a new folder. I'm going to call it SEC504. And now, I'm going to highlight all of the files from the ISO media file and drag and drop it into my SEC504 folder on my desktop. This copy process will take a few minutes to complete here, so we'll resume the video when the copy is finished. Great.

Once the file copy finishes, we can eject the ISO media file content here from Finder. And then we'll have the SEC504 folder on our desktop, and this will be our working folder for lab exercises. Inside of this folder, we're going to install Keka. Keka is an open-source compression utility that will allow us to quickly decompress the two virtual machine files. We've included the installation files for Keka in utilities, macos, and then, here, we see Keka. I'm going to double-click on that DMG file for Keka. And then I'm going to drag and drop Keka into my Applications folder. Okay. It only takes a couple seconds for Keka to finish installing here. That's all set. I'm going to close this.

And I'm going to go back to the SEC504 folder. And I'm going to go to my virtual_machines folder. We need to decompress the Slingshot Linux and the Windows 10 virtual machines. I'm going to right-click on this file and choose Open With Keka. Now, these 7-Zip files can also decompress with the Archive Utility, which is built into macOS. However, the Archive Utility is significantly slower than Keka. It will take considerably longer to decompress with the built-in Archive Utility. If you can't install Keka, then you could use that as an option, but I recommend using Keka for this. I'm going to choose Open With and then Keka, and then Keka will start the extraction process. I'm going to close this little notification here. This will take a little bit of time for Keka to be able to decompress the Slingshot Linux virtual machine, so we'll resume the video once Keka finishes. Great.

Once Keka finishes extracting the Slingshot Linux virtual machine, we can continue on to extract the Windows 10 virtual machine using the same procedure. I'm going to right-click on the Windows 10 virtual machine, Open With, and then choose Keka. This process, again, will take several minutes to complete, so we'll resume the video once Keka finishes extracting the virtual machine files.

Once Keka finishes extracting the Windows 10 virtual machine, you'll have the two virtual machine directories for Slingshot Linux and Windows 10. On my system, Keka put both of them on my desktop. Instead of the virtual_machines folder, you could either work with them from the desktop if that's convenient for you. I'm going to move them back into the virtual_machines folder just to keep everything nice and tidy and put together. Great.

At this point, we can close the Finder window, and we can open the VMware Fusion. I have copied it onto my desktop here for convenience, but you could start VMware Fusion from your launch tray or the Applications folder, whatever's convenient for you. And then from VMware Fusion, we can click File and then Open. Navigate to the desktop SEC504 folder, double-click, go to virtual_machines, and then choose Slingshot Linux. Select the VMX file, that's the virtual machine configuration file, then click Open. And then we can click the Play button to start the virtual machine. VMware will take a few seconds to boot up the Slingshot Linux virtual machine and make its way to the graphical user interface log-on screen, a couple more seconds here. Great.

When prompted, you can enter the password, sec504, to log into the virtual machine. And we can repeat this procedure for the Windows 10 virtual machine as well. Click File and then Open. Navigate to the desktop SEC504 folder, then virtual_machines, then the Windows 10 folder, and then choose the VMX file and click Open. Click the Play button to start the virtual machine. VMware will prompt you, only on the Windows virtual machine, if this VM has been moved or copied, and we are going to choose I Copied It, and VMware will start to boot the Windows virtual machine as well. This will just take a few seconds to start up.

At the background screen here, we can double-click, accept the SANS EULA for the license agreement for the use of this Windows virtual machine. And then when prompted for a password, enter the password, sec504, all lowercase letters. And this will bring us to the desktop interface for the Windows virtual machine.

Now, for both of these virtual machines, I like to full screen them. So I'm going to click the Enter full screen button here. And then I can use, on my Mac, a four-fingers swipe to be able to go to my other desktop, and I'm going to repeat that full screen for the Slingshot Linux virtual machine as well. And the virtual machines will now allow me to see them and maximize my screen real estate, which is nice when we have multiple terminals and the lab directions all open at the same time. And I can use four fingers to be able to swipe from Windows to Slingshot Linux and then back to my host operating system as well.

That's it for the setup directions for both the Slingshot Linux and Windows virtual machines for our Windows or Mac systems. And we're going to use these virtual machines in the lab files as we work through our lab exercises throughout the class. Nice work.
